awd_titl_txt: Decoding the Complex Cellular Information Flow by Multiplexed Chemosensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will significantly improve our understanding of cellular information flow in the presence of complex environment cues. Cells respond to external stimuli through a cascade of events involving messenger elements that transduce information at diverse scales. Despite the progress in revealing individual signaling pathways, the fact that most signal transducers are shared by multiple pathways challenges our current understanding of cellular information flow. Compared to telecommunication systems, cells are excellent multiplexing (MUX) and demultiplexing (DEMUX) devices handling huge amount of information within an interweaving signaling network. In particular, as one of the most multitasking messenger elements, intracellular calcium engages in many aspects of cellular functions. However, existing models of information routing have either limited applicability in calcium signaling or may underestimate its information capacity. 

Inspired by his recent findings of the calcium homeostasis during collective chemosensing, the PI hypothesizes that the non-linear dynamics of cytosolic calcium allows mammalian cells to encode complex information on both the single cell and multicellular levels. The PI proposes to test the hypothesis by studying the multiplexed chemosensing of a genetically engineered model cell line. As an essential step of the PI's long term goal to understand the physics of cellular information processing, the project will not only provide insight to the calcium-mediate  MUX/DEMUX mechanisms, but also pave the way of realizing its engineering potential to build cell-based biosensors and biocomputational units. The PI will develop a diverse educational and outreach program that is closely integrated with the research program. Specifically: (i) Utilizing existing programs at Oregon State University (OSU), the PI will design a series of lab-based research training projects to engage female and minority high school students, summer undergraduate interns as well as senior undergraduate students working toward their thesis. (ii) Results and data generated in the project will be used to develop quantitative biology curricula to be offered at OSU from the winter term of 2014. This class is designed to discuss biological systems from information processing perspectives. (iii) Industrial outreach will benefit from the PI's existing industrial partnership and the proposed outreach activities, such as site visits and graduate student internships to disseminate the research outcomes.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

por.por_cntn:
Cells respond to external stimuli through a cascade of events involving messenger molecules that transduce information at diverse scales. Despite the progress in revealing individual signaling pathways in isolated single cells, most signal transducers are shared by multiple pathways and among multiple cells in living systems. In order to close the knowledge gap that challenges the current understanding of cellular information flow, we study the calcium dynamics of communicating mammalian cells under external stimuli.

We find calcium dynamics of fibroblast cells encode rich information of their microenvironment. On the one hand, the fold increase of intracellular calcium concentration reliably reflects the amount of ATP molecules the cells are exposed to. On the other hand, communication between the cells through gap junctions causes the calcium concentration to oscillate in fibroblasts.

We have developed quantitative ways to characterize and understand both phenomena. In particular, we use information theory to measure the amount of information transduced from the environment to the cell calcium signaling. We find that a cell may take advantage of multiple measurements to gain better knowledge of its environment, but the process is limited by its memory capacity. We derive and experimentally test the lower and upper limits of the information gain, providing a useful way to estimate the information processing power of cells and to understand the optimal measuring strategies that a cell employs.

We find that a fibroblast cell typically respond to ATP in two distinct ways, either to have a single peak of intracellular calcium concentration or to have persistent calcium oscillations. These two types of responses arises due to the nonlinearity of the signaling dynamics, and calcium oscillation is necessary for successful wound healing. Surprisingly, we find that communications between the cells significantly increase the number of oscillating cells. Inversely, cutting down the communications such as by inserting cancer cells in a fibroblast colony discourages calcium oscillations. Our result therefore shows how efficiency of wound healing is fundamentally connected to cell-cell communications.

We find communications between the cells can also be mechanically mediated by tissue fibers that are created by fibroblasts. Such mechanical interactions can happen between normal cells, as well as between tumor cells. Calcium signaling is triggered by such interactions, therefore extending our findings into the context of cell migrations and cancer invasions.

Building on these scientific inquiries, we have been actively engaging general public through outreach programs. In particular, we have created mini-projects and hands-on demonstrations tailored for general public. We have organized annual workshops which attract more than one hundred local high school students, teachers, and college students to experience biophysics lab research. Over the past four years my lab has hosted 8 female high school internships for week-long summer research projects. These outreach programs not only help me to disseminate my scientific research, but also are part of the university-wide initiative to inspire a future generation of STEM workforce for the United States.
